element.name: Ranelagh Gardens by Hezekiah, Multi-cache (1/1.5)

center.font: Visit the new Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE

long-description.p: Located in Ranelagh and extending to 1 hectare (2.47 acres), the gardens were originally part of 5 hectares of pleasure gardens developed in 1775 by a businessman who called them after Lord Ranelagh from Co. Wicklow. Lord Ranelagh had similar pleasure gardens beside the Thames in London. The first hot air balloon flight in Ireland was launched from the pleasure gardens by Richard Crosbie.

The gardens were later sold to a teaching order of nuns and in 1840 the convent there became totally enclosed and the gardens forgotten. When the lands were developed for housing in the mid 1980's, the current small park was designed to include an ornamental pool thereby restoring the two-hundred years historical connection with the original Ranelagh Gardens.

The coordinates above will lead you to the gates of the Gardens – there is plenty of disc parking nearby, and the 44 & 48A buses stop less than 50 metres away. The Luas line is also close by – in fact, the gateway to the gardens forms a supporting arch for one of the Luas line bridges.
To move on to the cache location, multiply the number of park entrances (A) by 5 and add the result to the N coordinates given above (N53 19.600 + (A*5)) = N53 19.???)
Next, calculate the number of years the Carmelite nuns had a monastery here – (BCD). To get the W coordinates, subtract ((A+B)*D) from 006 15.385.
You now have the co-ordinates of the cache location – there may be some interference from trees and buildings, so there’s a clue below!

element.encoded-hints: 1 metre up a tree, hidden in the ivy!

ul.li:
2010-06-06T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by tolmaion
I failed to find this cache before. With the coordinates recently updated, I gave it another try today. Unfortunately, no joy. The final coordinates took me just outside the park to a place that matched the hint... but I could not locate any container.

2010-05-19T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by THE_Chris
Couldnt find it either tonight :( Had a look in what I thought was the obvious place given the hint, and some other nearby areas, but couldnt find the box :(
Will try again. Nice park, loads of ducks and lots of carp. And a would-be couple talking about what it would be like to be a duck.

2010-05-15T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by lamm4
It was a nice location, a realy nice park, but unfortunately the cache didn't shown up.[:[]

2010-05-08T19:00:00Z : Found it by salt'n'light
Lovely gardens, nice to see a new area of Dublin. TFTC

2010-04-18T19:00:00Z : Found it by Toffee Man
Found with Blue Jay 59 on a lovely day for caching. TFTC Toffee Man #301

2008-08-28T19:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
A lovely evening so we thought we'd pop out and grab this one. The cache hasn't been found for quite some time, and as a result it has collected rather a large amount of canine number ones which is a bit icky - highly recommend gloves and sanitiser spray! We replaced about a metre off the ground so that it's less likely to suffer this indignity again.

2008-03-02T23:58:19Z : Needs Maintenance by Kersti.com
Fire at location reported and confirmed. I couldn't find it - area extremely exposed. Suggest maintenance.

2008-03-01T20:00:00Z : Didn't find it by Kersti.com
Was passing so decided to pop in and take a look at this one. Had read the previous logs about the fire so took that into account. The location is fairly obvious but we could not spot the cache. Can I suggest some maintenance soon...

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Ranelagh Gardens
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description: Visit the new Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Located in Ranelagh and extending to 1 hectare (2.47 acres), the gardens were originally part of 5 hectares of pleasure gardens developed in 1775 by a businessman who called them after Lord Ranelagh from Co. Wicklow. Lord Ranelagh had similar pleasure gardens beside the Thames in London. The first hot air balloon flight in Ireland was launched from the pleasure gardens by Richard Crosbie.

The gardens were later sold to a teaching order of nuns and in 1840 the convent there became totally enclosed and the gardens forgotten. When the lands were developed for housing in the mid 1980's, the current small park was designed to include an ornamental pool thereby restoring the two-hundred years historical connection with the original Ranelagh Gardens.

The coordinates above will lead you to the gates of the Gardens – there is plenty of disc parking nearby, and the 44 & 48A buses stop less than 50 metres away. The Luas line is also close by – in fact, the gateway to the gardens forms a supporting arch for one of the Luas line bridges.

To move on to the cache location, multiply the number of park entrances (A) by 5 and add the result to the N coordinates given above (N53 19.600 + (A*5)) = N53 19.???)

Next, calculate the number of years the Carmelite nuns had a monastery here – (BCD). To get the W coordinates, subtract ((A+B)*D) from 006 15.385.

You now have the co-ordinates of the cache location – there may be some interference from trees and buildings, so there’s a clue below!
